plist.p: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for attending this full year 2012 presentation here in our offices in London. The presentation will be structured as usual, three different speeches. The first one to be given by our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Ignacio Galán, then Mr. José Luis San Pedro will explain in detail the latest development in the Spanish regulation.

The presentation will be in Spanish, so I highly recommended you to take these operators for translation that you have on the back on the room. And finally, Mr. José Sáinz, CFO, who will explain the results in detail.

The Q&A session is as usual, first, the question from the room, then the one coming from the telephone. And finally, the one received from the website. Finally, the duration of this presentation maximum probably will be in the range of 90 minutes.
Mr. Chairman?

So good morning, everyone. Thank you very much for attending this presentation for those who are here physically in London and those who is now connected to the webcast. I always appreciate very much your interest in our company.

Following our presentation in the October 2014 outlook that we present here in London, we would like to start saying that Iberdrola is on track to achieve the objectives set for the period. In the most difficult year experienced in the last decade, affected by both economic crisis and regulatory uncertainty, the company has continued to achieve improved results. Sales have increased 8.1% up to €34.2 billion and in spite of a lower production registering 2012 and thanks to better prices. EBITDA went up 1% to €7.7 billion, 75% for which came from regulations on our business.

Operating cash flow has increased 2.5% reaching €6.2 billion and contributing to strength in liquidity position of the company. Investment accounted by for €3.2 billion in line with our 2012-2014 plan. We also progressed positively in the completement of our divestment plan by signing an agreement to sell assets for €850 million, of which €400 million will be cash alone first semester 2013.

All of the above has allowed the company to reduce net debt, which fell by €1.4 billion along the year. And finally, net profit has increased 9.3 percentage, a ceiling once more during the crisis €2.8 billion. Adjusted sales have increased 8.1% in the period boosting gross margin to €12.6 billion with increase of 4.6%. In network develop contribution of Spain due to the reduction of distribution and remuneration is offset by the improvement raised in United Kingdom and the states in Brazil.

Renewables has significantly contributed to the positive evolution of their gross margin, thanks to 10.7% increase in production based on a higher leverage load factor and the growth in operating capacity. Finally, generation and supply has already a positive contribution to growth in gross margin thanks to higher prices and increased customer base and in spite of the lower production.

EBITDA in the period increased 1% to €7.7 billion by businesses and that will register a 1.4% decline as the considerable increase in the UK and United States are only able to partially offset the increase in Spain and Brazil, whose EBITDA once eliminated the evaluation of the Brazilian real effect remains flat.

Renewables, on the contrary, rose by 13.8% thanks to the increase in group margin, 10.5% and the efficiency gains that have allowed the company to keep net operating expenses flat along the period. Generation and supply shows an EBITDA increase of 3.7% with a good performance in all areas, especially in United Kingdom where we have considerably increased the number of customers with a significant reduction of cost per unit.

All in all, as I mentioned before, 75% of EBITDA comes from the regulated renewable businesses, they're more stable in predictable activities in those times. This predictability of cash flows is one of Iberdrola's differential features over the competitors. But in the year 2006, when Iberdrola began its international expansion, our businesses mix was similar to that of our European peers today with a much longer contribution of the liberalized business to EBITDA. Three years later, three quarters of our EBITDA come from regulated and record businesses while the European peer remain in 47%.

Iberdrola's net profit in 2012 amounts to €0.841 million, with an increase of 1.3% thanks to the international expansion that last year's 45% comes from UK and United States, 20% for Latin America while profit in Spain accounts for 30% of total results. Iberdrola has the most traded – this has taken the right decision to deal with a tough economic environment the last years. The focus in regulated businesses achieved through its internationalization phase has allowed the company to obtain solid and sustainable result in 2008 while CESPs had declined in the volatile results.

Following one of our main 2014 guidelines in 2012, all our business integrated cash flows exceeding net investment. Total operating cash flows amount €6.2 billion, growing 2.5%. After deducting investment, this figure almost reaches €3 billion. Also, according to the provision of the 2012-2014 outlook, Iberdrola has suggested investment to €3.3 billion to the end of 2012. 61% we are signed the networks and 23% to renewables.

By geographic areas, almost 50% of our total investment were addressed to United Kingdom and United States, in line with the contribution to the net profits. For our divestment plan in 2012, Iberdrola has signed agreements to sell non-core assets and assets in non-core countries for €850 million, completing 40% of our prerogative. Among others, we agreed the sale of our wind farms in Germany and France and our stake in Gas Natural Mexico and Medgaz.

Other operation in the final state of negotiation will be announced in the next few days. We are confident that the complete fulfillment of our €2 billion divestment plan will be sufficient to meet our net debt reduction estimate for 2012-2014 outlook. I would like to stress that with financial management put in 2012 have allowed us to preserve our financial strength in a very difficult environment.

We have reduced net debt in almost €1.4 billion. This amount reaches €2.2 billion once you include the cash receivable from deficit securitization, security in this first week of 2013 and from the divestment increase at the end of 2012 to be cast in 2013. This enabled Iberdrola to reduce our leverage from 48% last year in 2011 to 47% including the financing of tariff deficit, excluding the later leverage fall to 45%. Additionally, we have closed the year with a liquidity position of €12 billion, which covers more than 36 months of our financial needs.

Finally, we have had access to the capital and bank market in a favorable condition, enabling us to refinance our debt and maintain an average debt maturity around 6.2 years. Once included the last bond issue and for just (8:43) January 2013.

Now, Pepe Sáinz, the CFO, will explain the information with more detail. José Luis San Pedro, as was already mentioned, will make a brief description now of recent regulatory Iberdrola (8:58) in Spain, then I'm sure that you have already interest on it. Thank you.

Good morning to you. Basically, I'm going to give you a description and assessment of the three last measures published by the Spanish government 31st of December, over the Royal Decree Law in February and the draft version of the ministered order of feeding tariffs.

I should give you a brief description, first of all, of the most important regulatory measures, which you're already familiar with, and which have come out through – out 2012. Okay, the first of them is Royal Decree Law published in January 2012. It was a very quick measurement taken by the Ministry of Industry creating a moratorium for the new renewable energies and heat and power generation of cogeneration, i.e., all technologies which had incentives and which were not registered.

Now the second measure taken was an unexpected cutback, an unexplainable cutback, of remuneration of regulated transport and distribution networks. And the third was the fiscal measures published on the 26th of December, fiscal measures for energy sustainability, which account for seven – or five different tributes for different generation activities.

Now the first issue, the moratorium, seems to me was a reasonable measure since there was a growth in incentives. They were growing – were exponentially and sufficient at the same time because what should've been included were all of those plants – already registered plants but whose inflation had begun. Not having done so, meant that this year, the more than 1,500 megawatts of renewable energy came on the line.

The second decree, which affects the cutbacks in transport and distribution, was a very strong cutback, completely unexpected, and unjustified too. It doesn't answer any new model of remuneration for distribution, and my own personal opinion is that it should've been proposed by the National Energy Commission and published whereby a carry forward, not as a royal decree.

The third measure, the fiscal measures, which came out in due of the final publication was in December this year – sorry last year, is a five tribute, so taxes, all of them, are aimed to very clearly regulate and they're aimed at reducing the tariff deficit. There's a general tariff, a 7% tax which applies to all generation. We also had two other taxes, or tributes, nuclear and hydropower. We have another tax which is applied to fuels. The aim here is to reduce emissions. The coal – this is coal and gas consumption tax.

So the effects now of these taxes on the sector, of the levies on Iberdrola and our deficit as following, the first one, it is only applied to facilities we do not -that do not exist, had no short-term effect, although they will have substantial impact in the middle and the long-term. The second levy, i.e. on distribution for our sector, meant a cutback of our remuneration of €689 million on a total which is approximately €5 billion.

And for Iberdrola, it meant a drop in €234 million cutback in remuneration, which all these levies which are going to be applied in 2013, and which corresponds to Law 15/2012, came out on the 26th of December, meant a new fiscal load for Iberdrola – of €690 million per year for the sector, €3 billion – €3.6 billion per annum in other – for these two measures, in other words, which bring something like over €4 billion, the aim was to reduce the tariff deficit.

Now, as I've said before, when faced with these two new taxes, have an effect on the profit-loss account. The first one is the distribution. We try it here or we're trying to – we have tried and we will try to compensate this with a substantial reduction of our investments, that's like 50%, as well as a substantial reduction to our operating costs, both personnel costs and external services. And we've taken these measures, for example, reduced 400 head counts in the distribution and personnel in Spain, a reduction of external services too.

Now, turning to how we're going to look at the increase in taxes, €680 million – €690 million. This will depend a great deal on the rest of the sector, mainly how those units which are secondary or non-core, which might transfer to the price of these taxes. For example, for coal, all of these levies accounts for an increase of price between €9 and €10 per megawatt hour. In gas, something like €7. Now these are units which are marginal and which are going to pay for the price of energy.

Now insofar as these costs are passed on, because of tax to the price of energy, an important part of these taxes, of the €3.6 billion, don't know how much will be passed on to the customer via the final price for energy.

Now let's look at more up-to-date things. It was the 31 of December, I believe. The Spanish government had brought out a Royal Decree Law, which had two aims. One, was it recognized the deficit stipulated for 2012, which it was €1.5 billion, had been exceeded with €5.5 billion. The basic result of this deviation, well, various reasons for them, but the main one was that part of the income which we were counted on to increase costs in the sector were not put in the general budget of the state.

For example, the operating incentives which are given for islands to compensate for the costs they support above the average peninsula cost. And so therefore, the first thing the government had to do in this Royal Decree Law is they recognized that they have not fulfilled their deficit objective and that the deficit had been accepted – exceeded a great deal.

Now the second aim, and this is a positive one, it seems to me, if this law had been applied as it was, without this new Royal Decree, this excess of deficit should have been passed on automatically to the 2013 tariffs, giving rise to a substantial increase in tariffs, and particularly, giving rise to regulatory uncertainty in this sector, which was pretty substantial because if the tariffs increase a great deal, the aim of the government would have been to try to find new cutbacks in the sector.

This has not been the case. It has been – this capital has been recognized as a securitization deficit. We could securitize it or give it this year – or seed it this year, through the company Ibea (17:35) the company which is looking at the securitization of all this issue and it could be securitized this year and the following year.

Now, so it has been a realistic royal decree on one hand, and on the other hand, it's not been too good – not too bad for our sector. Let's look at the last two measures now. The Royal Decree Law 12 of 2013 defined as urgent measures for electric and financial sectors.

As regarding the electric sector, first of all, the first measure is that in the rate of – I'm sorry, the uptake rate which has been used now to uptake the value of incentives of premiums and in general, all regulated costs, was the IPC minus 5.5 points of the retail price index, the RPI, sorry. So the numbers of the RPI are desegregated from the energy costs and other levies.

Now, the effect of this change has a negative effect which is one-off, because in the long-term as a trend, these two rates would need to be similar. And then the change of the index has a logical reason for it, the regulated costs are not – did not have a great deal to do with the increase in taxes and don't have rate include energy costs. So the measure as a measure has its logic behind it but it does have a negative effect on remuneration of the sector for 2013.
The reason is that in 2012, the RPI was highly conditioned by taxes for example, basically VAT, so part of the 3% of the increase of the RPI last year was due to an increase in VAT.

Now the second measure is the – it's a substantial change in the remuneration system and the special regime. So those facilities have a special regime, which wants to go to the market – don't give premiums or don't want to go to the market but have to go to a tariff regime.

Now this measure, from my own point of view, has two important effects. First of all, is that it didn't seem to be reasonable or logical that a renewal of technology could go between markets and going to the tariff because the forecast for market price has been low. Well now I'm going – not to the market because the prices are going to be high. This kind of arbitrage in a business, which is purely regulated, didn't make much sense. And so from the conceptual point of view, this measure doesn't really seem logical.

The second one, the most important reason for me, is that since we went from the markets to tariff, a reduction is essential because tariffs give you a remuneration with notably lower than what we've got on the market plus the premium.

And the third consequence, which seems to me important is that they don't even call it a premium, they're called tariffs. A tariff is something which is there to define in the criteria for remuneration and the value of this remuneration in the National Commission of Energy and the Ministry of Industry. In other words, currently again in my opinion, all renewables as well as transport and distribution are activities which are regulated, whose remuneration and whose procedures of calculation for that remuneration belong to the regulator, which are the National Energy Commission and the Spanish Ministry of Industry.

With that, we hope, is that all technologies would be dealt with in the future on an equal footing. We cannot think, for example, one regulated activity should be remunerated with a certain level of 6%, another one with 12%. This is the most important thing for me. These are the definition as a remuneration system for all the regulated businesses. And this is the whole thing about the tariff.

And finally, well, the effects. What about the effects, which this has had on this sector, on Iberdrola itself, of this Royal Decree Law has been a change in the system of updating, of retribution, of remuneration. The RPI, retail price index, without levies and treaty (22:38) and this is a reduction of cutback in the distribution transfer of €10 million and, in sector as a whole, €70 million.

And then we have a special regime. This effect, plus the change to tariff for Iberdrola, means a cutback of €100 million of the sector as a whole, €600 million. In other words, with this Royal Decree, in addition to other objectives which are, where we regulated, means a drop in the deficit for 2013 of €670 million. For Iberdrola, the cutback in this remuneration falls by €110 million, but we'll see that there are other aspects which are contemplated in what I'm going to be talking about. This is the proposal of tariff orders and it sort of completely obliterates these effects as you'll see shortly.

Now the proposal of the tariff order, which has not come out yet is still a proposal. It's in draft. Maybe it'll come out tomorrow or on Friday. The idea is to freeze feeding tariffs, i.e. there will be no increase in access tariffs or feeding tariffs. And secondly, most importantly, it's believed that the whole series of new income, which will tend to finance the regulated cost of the sector.

What are these new sources of income? First of all, the levies or taxes which are going to be got or gotten with this layer of sustainability which came out 26 of December, which I've just mentioned. The calculation of tariffs is regarded as €2.9 billion. Now in our calculations, some €3.5 billion can be found. But initially, the law says that either the general budget of the state only take onboard €2.9 billion, although we believe this figure will be higher.

The second effect is that 90% of the revenues from the auctions of CO2 emissions will reduce the tariff deficit. This has been calculated €450 million. It seems to me, these government figures, that this is optimistic. Bear in mind, the quotations we have for CO2, the third which was the most surprising of all is that a credit, an extraordinary credit from the government to the Ministry of Industry for the €2.2 billion to tackle not only sector costs of this credit, but the ministry, or the regulator, will be using – gradually using as first initial settlements as we get negative results. In other terms, initially, this credit will replace financing which has been given to companies to date.

Now in addition to this, it's a grant, it's a non-returnable grant, it's public debt regarded as this, it's also regarded as public debt, I repeat. And finally, this whole tariff order, like the previous one, also considers that in the island incentives for 2013, which is €1.7 billion, will be regarded as expenditure in the general state budget for 2014 and therefore they will not consume tariff deficit.

Now these are – this is new revenue if you add them all up, the final figure I believe is – I've written it down somewhere – €7.3 billion, something like that. Again, another positive aspect is that we have a whole series of costs which are recognized for 2013 and which have already been recognized in previous years but have not been paid to us. I'm talking more specifically about the fact that we have €732 million for costs of transport and distribution and to compensate or offset the incentives which we had assigned to us for improvement in the quality of the service or a result of leakages of energy loss.

Total amount of costs which applied – we don't know the – what I'm talking about something like €500 million for distribution but it will be applied on – part of it will be in cash flow because they recognize this from past years and part will be on income, accounted income for 2013. Now after that, the regulation system changes of the interim for customers who can do this or the interruptions, we have an increase in costs but this does not affect us directly nor does it affect our deficit.

And finally, it also considers provisions. We'll see whether these are implemented or not, which will come out €308 million earmarked for updating the financial cost, which we have to finance our debt. I'm talking about five companies in a sector which are – have recognized – has recognized 2% as a ruling of the Supreme Tribunal is that we should have all of these costs recognized. They devote part from €200 million – €250 million to the updating of this kind, of this interest rates. Then we have the €100 million to be given, to be returned by the ruling of the Supreme Tribunal certain payments for certain aspects or certain items.

Now, so here, we have the calculation for the forecast for our tariff deficit 2013, which is done by the Spanish ministry by the way. The regulated costs, without an increase in tariffs and with an increase in demand of minus 0.2%, is simple, I think. The other income I've already mentioned – CO2 auctions, fiscal measures and government or extraordinary credit access costs or feeding costs.

Fixed data, you know this already, special regime as we go and add new facilities with the same as we've had to date or calculated in line with the price of electrical tariff. Transport intuition against a fixed figure deficit or annual deficit which are pending or which are securitized, again, fixed figure. Depend deposits, depends on interest so I'd say that of this calculation, we have three uncertainties. One, if the demand is going to grow, so minus zero two or minus – zero minus one.

Here we have an uncertainty of – the other one is the fiscal one for €21 million. And if these are carried out as the law, if we carry out all incomes would bring down the deficit, we could have €3.5 billion. Now the third uncertainty is to see whether in 2014, the ministry is going to take charge of the cost of the incentives, which are paid to the islands, i.e., €1.7 billion. I'd say that all told, a reasonable probability we've not seen in the past is that we can fulfill this deficit. Although we'll be very clear if we don't get it, we'll get near to it.

Now by way of conclusion, on these last few measures, what I say here is that at least initially, these three measures have a neutral effect, if they have any, on Iberdrola's financial results. Secondly, that these measures, at least from my point of view and from the regulatory point of view, seemed to be correct, to be right. They made later foundations to have a regulation system, which is stable and transparent visibility.

And thirdly, the calculation of the deficit made by the government for 2013 seems to me, personally, pretty realistic. Having said – that said, I'd like to add that I also believe that in spite of a fact that there had been very harsh measures for this sector as was for the consumer, I believe it's reasonable to think that with these measures in 2013, we will put an end, for once and for all, with the tariff deficit.
That's all I have to say. Thank you very much for your attention.

Good morning. So we shall now proceed briefly to analyze the relevant issues of the income statement, the performance of the different businesses and the group's financial situation. The chairman has pointed out, despite the difficult environment, the group shows a 1% and a 2.5% growth in EBITDA and customer generation and reported net profit is up 1.3%.

Net sales are up 8.1% to €3.4 billion and procurements froze 11.2% to €21.5 billion, maintaining the growth trend during the year. Gross margins increased 4.6% to almost €12.6 billion, thanks to the higher international activity and the positive foreign exchange impact. The basic margin is up 3.5% to €12.7 billion, slightly below the growth of the gross margin as revenues from CO2 allowances fell 51% due to CO2 lower prices and consumption.

Net operating expenses are up 7.7%, due to higher nonrecurring personnel expenses associated with efficiency plans that will have its returns in next year some plant closures. But recurrent net operating expenses were up only 1.5%, mainly due to the Elektro consolidation. They would have been flat otherwise or would have fallen 1.9% excluding the FX impact. Net personnel expenses rose 11.9% due to a €160 million of non-recurring costs related to efficiency plans and plant closures, recurrent net personnel expenses rose 1.7%.

Net external services were up 4.4% considering a net €23 million negative impact of non-recurring expenses associated mainly with penalties paid in 2012. Recurring net external services rose 1.3%. Levies are up 6.9%, despite the favorable Spanish Supreme Court ruling that exempts generation companies from financing the social tariff, the social bonus and the reversion of Castilla-La Mancha eco tax after a positive court ruling. The increase is due to the higher local taxes in Spain and higher costs related to the CERT/CESP programs in the UK, where levies have increased €134 million due to the requirement to be completed in 2012.

In Spain, levies were up 12.3%, excluding these court rulings. Nevertheless, there are several taxes that Iberdrola has appealed, still pending on court decisions that hopefully, we will have impact positively in our P&L in these next years. As already explained by the chairman, the 1% growth in EBITDA is driven by our international activities, which account for 52% of total EBITDA and for a positive FX impact of €114 million. Both generation and supply and renewals have seen their EBITDA rising 3.7% and 13.8% respectively.

While networks EBITDA fell 1.4% to €3.8 billion due to the cuts imposed by the Royal Decree that José Luis has just mentioned to €133 million on the Spanish networks and a fourth quarter one-off impacts in Brazil and the U.S. Spain represent 35% of EBITDA, the UK 25%, the U.S. 18% and Brazil 22%.

The Q4 one-off can be explained in the U.S. by the impact of the Sandy hurricane that has had a negative impact of €48 million for our operations in the U.S. and that will be recovered in the next first case. In Brazil due to the drought, distribution companies have to buy thermal capacity despite at higher prices that will be passed through to the consumers in the next yearly review period. So we are right now buying at higher prices but that will be passed to the consumers in the next review period.

There has been for that reason another minor reasons, a €74 million negative impact due to the IFRS accounting methodology. If we would have been accounting this through GAAP, we wouldn't have seen this impact on the accounts.

The review month for Elektro is August and for Neo is April. So as I was mentioning, the negative impact should be compensated by a positive one after the review has happened. The impact is a spread during one year until the next review, so this negative impact is compensated through a one year after the month of August in the case of Neo, in the case of Elektro, and in the case of Neo after April.

Nevertheless, the outlook for 2013 in Brazil still is challenging. In addition to the drought that continues and we are seeing these negative impacts in the months of January and February, there is also a lack of access to generation PPAs as auctions were canceled and producers are selling their electricity in the sport market. This is forcing Elektro to buy around 8% of its needs again in the market at higher prices with the same negative accounting impact as the drought. So, this will be also be recovered in the next tariff review.

EBITDA in Spain networks fell 13.3% due to the €233 million cut as I mentioned, which represents an 8.5% drop in the regulated revenues. As a consequence, the gross margin fell 8.2%. Net operating expenses grew 6.5% due to higher non-recurring costs linked to efficiency measures as José Luis just pointed. That will provide a positive impact in the following years.

Also, levies increased by 20% due to higher local taxes. EBITDA in UK networks was up 12.6% to €937 million, driven by the higher revenues as a consequence of the record investments of €560 million that Storage Power has done in the UK this year in distribution and a positive impact of this appreciation of the sterling of 6.6%. So the EBITDA in pounds was up 5.2%. Net operating expenses increased by €30 million due to the higher costs associated with the complying of the DP share of (39:42) regulatory targets and the FX impact.

The U.S. network's EBITDA under IFRS rose 20.5% to €660 million, including a positive impact of €50 million but compensated with its €48 million negative impact of the Sandy. So, the underlying positive – the underlying evolution of the business has been very positive and we are close to our return on equity targets. This has been caused by higher revenues from the red cases and an increased contribution from the main transmission line, despite also the sale of some non-regulated companies.

Despite the dollar strength, there is also an improvement in net operating expenses due to some non-recurring conditions and the different scope of consolidation. EBITDA in Brazil has decreased 7% to €827 million as a result of the fourth quarter mentioned impacts with an impact of €74 million at EBITDA level together with the Elektro lower tariff in place as you know since August 2012.

The 4.6% increase in demand and the full consolidation of Elektro are more than compensated by the above mentioned negative effects. In addition to this, we have an exchange rate adverse impact in the case of the real of €63 million. Net operating expenses were up 23%, due basically to the Elektro full consolidation and the additional activity of the companies.

Now we will analyze the generation and supply business that includes Spain, UK and Mexico. EBITDA is up 3.7% to €2.3 billion, improving the fall of 1.7% at September with good performance, as the chairman has mentioned, in all areas, as lower outputs and higher costs are more than offset by better prices and positive FX impact.

Spain has had a better performance growing 2.2% compared to the almost flat September EBITDA. This, together with the good evolution of the business in the UK and a positive FX impact in Mexico, compensates the €221 million negative impact of the third CESP programs in the UK. Net operating expenses are up 12% mainly due to nonrecurring efficiency measures in Spain and the UK.

Levies are up 1.4% as the favorable Spanish Supreme Court ruling that exempts generation companies does not compensate the increase in local taxes. And obviously, the (42:34) impact. About the generation and supply business in Spain is worth highlighting that demand was down 1.4% in 2012.

Iberdrola output in the ordinary regime has been down 15%, driven by a 39% lower hydro production and a 64% lower combined cycle production, partially compensated by a 7.1% increase in nuclear production. The basic margin is slightly down. Net operating expenses increased by 10%, due to nonrecurring effects and other expenses related to supply business.

Excluding nonrecurring, net operating expenses in this business is down 3.9%. On the other hand, the lower levies as a consequence of the Spanish Supreme Court ruling about the social bonus compensates the slightly drop of the basic margin. However, excluding this effect, levies are up 7.2%. EBITDA is finally up 2.2% to €1.6 billion.

For 2013, 45 terawatt hours of production have been sold on prices similar to last year. The basic margin in the UK generation and supply business has reached €1.1 billion, a 23% increase maintaining the growth path of September, driven mainly by the supply business with margins recovering since minimum levels in 2011, thanks to the improvement in the procurement cost and a 7.7% increase in new customers, which is very important.

It also reflects a positive FX impact of €75 million. All of these effects more than compensate the 20% lower output due to plant stoppages and lower gas spreads that have affected the business. Tariff increases compensate the higher non-energy cost that suppliers are suffering in the UK. Net operating expenses have risen 8.2%, affected by efficiency measures and the appreciation of the pound.

Finally, as levies have increased €138 million due to these programs, EBITDA growth is lower to 4.5% in British pounds. EBITDA in Mexico grew 5% to €380 million. The operating performance of the business shows a 9.5% rise in gross margin level with better margins compensating plant outages and with a positive FX impact.

Net operating expenses have increased €24 million, €9 million of them out of the FX impact and the rest from non-recurring items as lower compensation from suppliers that we had for damages in 2011. Renewables improves its performance as the 4% higher operating capacity to 13,735 megawatts and a 2.5% higher load factor to 26.3% resulted in a 10.7% higher output to 31,784 gigawatt hours with growth in all geographic areas that has driven EBITDA of 13.8% to €1.6 billion. The main drivers, as mentioned, are the 10.7% higher output and the higher average prices, €71 per megawatt hour versus €69 per megawatt hour in 2011, due to the exchange rate evolution and the higher contribution of the areas with a higher selling price.

Net operating expenses are flat due to non-recurrent expenses, but there is a 4.6% improvement of net operating expenses per megawatt. All these factors have driven a 15.8% growth in EBITDA from the pure renewable activities. The installed capacity is up 14,034 megawatts or 2.5% up after the sale of the wind farms in France and Germany. So we have already taken away the wind farms in France and Germany from this figure.

EBIT drops 2.8% showing a worse evolution on EBITDA mainly due to a 7.6% increase in amortizations due to plant closures, the integration of Elektro and the investments in networks and renewables partially compensated by the increase in the useful life of wind farms. The 1.1% increase in provisions included in 2012 write-offs linked to renewables canceled projects, some nonrecurring provisions in Brazil related to bad debt, another write-offs that we have accounted in gas assets in the U.S. 2011 including almost €300 million of provision related to thermal assets, mainly Longannet, which have been replaced by the previously mentioned write-offs.

The net financial results have increased 3.6% to minus €1.1 billion driven by two factors. First, the interest expense that are €19 million more than last year.
